description: From Late Middle English somete, from early Middle French somete, from Old French sommette, somet (compare modern French sommet), a diminutive of som (“highest part, top of a hill”), from Latin summum.

entries.meaning: (countable) A peak; the topmost point or surface, as of a mountain.
examples: In summer, it is possible to hike to the summit of Mount Shasta.

entries.meaning: (countable) A gathering or assembly of leaders.
examples: They met for an international summit on environmental issues.

verbs.description: summit (third-person singular simple present summits, present participle summiting or summitting, simple past and past participle summited or summitted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, hiking, climbing, colloquial) To reach the summit of a mountain.
examples: Of the range's 12 peaks, Mount Saskatchewan is the only one that has yet to be summited.

description: From Middle English *summit, *sumwit, *sumwiht, variant of sum wiht, som wiht (“some thing”, literally “some wight”). More at some, wight.
